headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Genaida and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being rec
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Genaida and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Eric Boyriven. Please proceed.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for the L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. 2011 Fourth Quarter Conference Call.With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Fi
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for the L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. 2011 Fourth Quarter Conference Call.
With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After formal remarks, management will be available to take your questions.
Please note that during this call, management will reiterate forward-looking statements that were made in the press release issued this morning. Please refer to this press release, as well as the company's SEC filings, for a more detailed description of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Also please note that this call is being simultaneously broadcast over the Internet.
I would now like to turn the call over to Michael Strianese. Mike, please go ahead.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning for our year end earnings call. I'd like to start by thanking our employees again delivering L-3 solid performance, strong program execution under the leadership of our group
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning for our year end earnings call. I'd like to start by thanking our employees again delivering L-3 solid performance, strong program execution under the leadership of our group President continuous to be a performance driver for us and remains a differentiator for the company.
Our GAAP earnings in the fourth quarter were $2.72 per share on a diluted basis, despite the persistent challenging economic environment. Excluding some unusual items, EPS was $2.54, which is 7% up versus the 2010 fourth quarter. Our free cash flow is also strong, generating just shy of $0.5 billion. The exact number is $4.98 billion for the quarter. Sales for the quarter were $4 billion, led by 8% growth in C3ISR, which partially offset headwinds in our other segments. We ended the year with sales of $15.2 billion, which is a 3% decrease when compared to 2010. 
Orders were 3.2 billion for the quarter and 14.8 billion for 2011, which resulted in a book-to-bill ratio of 0.97 for the year. Our funded backlog was $10.7 billion at year end.
Overall, we returned over $1.1 billion of cash to our shareholders in 2011 through share repurchases and dividends, representing an increase overall of 13% in cash returned versus in 2010. And I'll note that since inception of our share repurchase plan, we have repurchased about 45 million shares or roughly 1/3 of our outstanding stock with about 13 million of those shares coming in 2011 alone. 
Our commitment to value and responsible deployment of cash extends our investment in technology and innovation despite the budget downturn, I read those remain a priority for us. We will continue in invest our cash in R&D and activities to expand our business space.
Looking at the business segments. ISR had strong performance showing solid growth on healthy customer demand. Our AM&M contract logistics support business performed well with recent competitive wins, a steadily increasing backlog and a growing market share. The difficult budget environment and lower JCA volume for AM&M were partially offset by CLS services were particularly for the armies C12 aerial Surveillance aircraft. Our Electro-Optical infrared integrated sensors business experienced increased volume within the Electronic Systems segment. The troop withdrawal from Iraq and the drawdown in Afghanistan resulted in program declines that continued to impact our services business. As I said at the onset of the call, L-3 has been able to demonstrate consistently strong program performance defined in part by operating more efficiently and anticipating our customer needs with innovative products and services.
That performance was recognized by the customer when our army fleet support unit received the 2011 Material Readiness award from the Army Aviation Association of America. This prestigious honor is awarded to a defense contractor that has made an outstanding contributions to the material readiness of army aviation. And given the upcoming recovery, that has is very happy going into 2012.
We continue to look closely at our operations to ensure that they align well with our production requirements and help us achieve maximum efficiencies. This involves making sure that our businesses are sized appropriately and are focused upon on delivering for our customers. We continued to integrate and consolidate our businesses with backhaul in mind. 
We're also concentrating on adding new capabilities that expand our product lines and broaden our customer base. In 2011, our fire businesses contributed about $160 million to our net sales. A good example of our strategy to add capability and broaden our base is the recently-announced acquisition of Kollmorgen Electro-Optical, which develops and manufactures specialized equipment such as submarine, photonic systems and periscopes, ship fire control systems, visual landing aids and ground EO and sensing systems. KEO also expands our base in the EO/IR market and strengthen our position as a mission-critical sensor systems provider.
KEO is a market leader and positioned in very high priority areas in the DoD budget, including the Virginia class submarine. It also creates a variety of technical synergies and pull through opportunities for us that enhance our offerings in situational awareness our customers. And KEO demonstrates how we successfully execute our cetacean strategy of carefully and selectively considering opportunities for excellent value and provide a good fit IR with our current mix of businesses. 
As you know, we've announced the acquisition in December. We expect it to close over the next couple of weeks. And again, KEO is a market leader in its space and when next combined with our existing EO/IR business, you can imagine some of the synergies we will see from the technology standpoint and the broadening of our portfolio products and customers. So really, it's a nice fit. We are excited about getting that close in the next couple of weeks.
With regards to M&A in general, we're going to continue the strategy of being vigilant and disciplined in seeking out opportunities that contribute to our growth and help us drive customer advances and expand our market positions. We've been very sensitive that the pricing on acquisitions that we want to be absolutely sure that we're going to be delivering shareholder value when we go forward.
Internationally, there are opportunities for L-3 including foreign military sales. We're already doing very well in certain regions. We have a wide range of products, both commercial and military, that are procured by international customers. This includes airborne ISR and centers, Aviation Security equipment, commercial shipbuilding, aviation products, sonar systems and unmanned and optionally piloted aircraft. We'll continue to look to expand internationally in areas that leads our strengths.
Regarding on an update on the Engility spinoff, we are proceeding on schedule. The management team and board are being assembled, and we anticipate IRS approval soon for the tax-free status of the spend. We expect the transaction to be completed by midyear around June 30. We believe in Engility's prospects going forward, independent of OCI constraints and with the streamlined operating structure to enhance its competitiveness. 
The remaining service businesses -- business which we're calling NSS or National Security solution have opportunities in areas where we have effective distribution channels in place. 
This allows us that for customers' end-to-end capabilities from sensors and products that securely move the data to processing systems that allowed the fire or government agency to use the data more effectively. The actions we're taking with Engility and NSS demonstrate our strategy of focusing on our core strengths in areas that align well with our customer priorities. Regarding the budget, as we're all aware, the President will submit his budget on February 13. 
Last week, Secretary Pineda provided some guidance on the budgeting process. He emphasized that the military will be smaller and leaner while remaining agile and technologically advanced. He also outlined a focus on operations in the Asia Pacific and Middle East regions. He stressed protecting and prioritizing investment in key technologies including fiber capabilities, special operations forces, missile defense and countering weapons of mass destruction. The new defense budget will produce about $260 billion of savings over the next 5 years. And the Pentagon feels that a further around the cuts will inflict severe damage to our National Security for generations to come. And that it continues to support a scenario that does not sacrifice military readiness and the administration of firms and commitment to maintaining military superiority with a leaner force structure.
The administration, as well as senior leaders in both the House and Senate are working hard to avoid take the station in favor of a recently robust DoD budget. 
The important message here is that we will continue to see the savings achieved by DoD's initiatives invested in many of our core strengths such as C3ISR, EO/IR systems, special operations and intelligence support and counterterrorism. And will benefit such programs as the Virginia class submarine, combat ship and amphibious ships, as well as a bit in recent maintenance on aircraft helicopters and aircraft carriers.  We believed L-3 size and Engility are assets in this environment in responding to customers need, particularly in light with the DoD's new direction of focusing on more quick strike global actions and less on protracted ground works.
We'll continue to monitor the situation closely as it evolves over the coming months, and we'll provide you updates on our quarterly calls as we normally would. In terms of some of the significant milestones and awards during the quarter, we just shared with you a few of them. In C3ISR, we continue to see follow-on orders for well over 6, which provides real-time battlefield communications between ground forces, ships, aircraft and UASS. We received contracts in support of sustainment repayment programs from both global Hawk and Preditor. We receive follow-on order for additional ships and equipment for the Virginia class subs, or program mentioned by Secretary Pineda as the DoD priority.
We received additional funding for upgrades and logistics works on existing Project Liberty aircraft, demonstrating our across the segment capability, with sensors and Communication Systems from Electronic Systems and C3ISR businesses and in service platform system support provided by AM&M.
We received funding for capability enhancements to our Spider, small manned ISR aircraft for government and the national military and civilian use. That's a new product that was introduced in 2011, about midyear. It's gotten a lot of attention on the international stage as an affordable ready off-the-shelf platform that customers can try before they fly. And we are expecting to get some traction or orders in 2012. 
For AM&M, we continue to see good performance on our army fleet support contract logistics service and SFS contracts. And we received orders for administration and integration projects from OEMs such as Bombardier. With respect to the Joint Cargo Aircraft as you know it, we're not anticipating any additional orders from the Air Force. 
Internationally, Australia is currently considering FMS purchase of 10 aircraft-s. But consistent with our prior guidance, we think we have IT pegged correctly. We're not anticipating any additional orders from the Air Force.
With regard to Electronic Systems. Our Link Simulation and Training division want to re-compete for the U.S. Air Force F-16 Training System. We continue to receive strong orders for WestCam sensors, including systems for the armies aerostat initiative or EMARSS and helicopter programs as well, warrior systems product received order from the Army under the storm TI program on airport Security. The ProVision ATD system has strong international interest, including an order from Ireland recently. Our upgrade of increasing systems in the field to the image-free automated protection configuration is proceeding well. And we received an order from, that's in Canada for checked baggage systems.
We have orders from SATCOM equipment including the FSMS sell of the systems to the Iraqi MoD and a competitive win to provide the satellite control system for the next satellite constellation. And partnership with Lufthansa, an airport operator freight port, we have successfully demonstrated back in December our green taxing technology, which does not require the use of aircraft engines while taxiing, thus reducing fuel usage and resulting emissions. Now not only does it not require the engines but you might imagine, it doesn't require any of the pushback equipment either. So these are using hub-mounted motors that L-3 has developed to move an entire airplane around the airport including pushback from the runway. While it's still early stages, I would tell you that this a good example of transitioning some of our technology to green energy and commercial applications. Now it's a long way to get the production, but we had a very good start with this successful demo because it was quite a technological feat to move an airplane given the weight with a small hub-mounted motor.
We also received orders for submarine equipment from the Turkish Navy and we're selected as the sonar supplier to Indonesia. In addition, we received a number of international orders for our sonars. In services, we received competitive win to continue our work providing C4I systems integration operational work for Spyware. We continue to make good progress on classified programs, including receiving customer accolades for excellence in operations and engineering support. We also continue to receive contracts in support of the DOI program, which is formally known as Linguist.
With regard to capital allocation and acquisitions, our commitment to shareholder value has been consistent in terms of our focus on being disciplined in how we deploy our cash. During the quarter, we used the cash flow to repurchase 158 million of common stock and paid dividends of $45 million for the quarter, resulting in about 1.15 of cash returned to shareholders in 2011, 13% over the comparable amount in the comparable mix in 2010 of buybacks and dividends. 
Our commitment to capital allocation also focuses on M&A. And at the same time, we remain committed to preserving our investment grade credit ratings. We'll continue to aggressively pursue value patient using our existing strategy of addressing customer priorities, managing costs to enhance competitiveness and grow earnings and balance capital deployment.
I'm going to turn it over to Ralph to go through some of the numbers in the fourth quarter and as 2012 guidance, and then we'd be happy to take your questions. So Ralph, take it away.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Mike. Good morning. As Mike said, I'll add some comments about the fourth quarter results and talk about our 2012 guidance update. On the fourth quarter, our GAAP earnings share were $2.72. We had 2 unusual items affecting the quarterly r
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Mike. Good morning. As Mike said, I'll add some comments about the fourth quarter results and talk about our 2012 guidance update. On the fourth quarter, our GAAP earnings share were $2.72. We had 2 unusual items affecting the quarterly results. First, we had a gain of $78 million or $0.77 of EPS related to the resolution of prior-year tax contingencies. And secondly, we had recorded a non-cash impairment charge of $57 million or $0.49. Now most of that charge was for a little impairment at our Marine Services business, a small business in Electronic Systems segment that was due to a decline in its projected operations and cash flows. for these unusual items, the 2011 fourth quarter results were generally in line with our outlook. 
EPS was about $0.10 higher than we expected. And what happened there was higher segment operating margin, lower taxes, lower interest expense and shares outstanding combined to offset declining sales and drive the growth in EPS.
Fourth quarter sales were $4 billion and $15 million, down 5.6% versus the 2010 fourth quarter. Sales were lower than we expected by about $140 million, with most of the actual versus guidance difference in the Electronic Systems segment.
I characterized the lower sales as endemic of the slowing and now declining U.S. defense budget, coupled with a shorter cycle major of a lot of our businesses.
Segment operating margin improved 20 basis points to 11% versus the fourth quarter of last year. And that was 50 basis points higher than we expected. And what happened there was we had an improvement in our sales mix while with higher products versus services sales plus a more favorable product sales mix. The individual segment results are covered in the earnings release.
Free cash flow was very robust at $438 million, up 10% versus the fourth quarter of last year, bringing free cash flow for the full year to a very healthy $1.3 billion.
Before I move onto the 2011 -- or sorry, 2012 guidance update, I want to add 1 point about the fourth quarter goodwill impairment charge. As you know, L-3 has a large goodwill asset balance. And depending on how events unfold the next 12 to 24 months around the U.S. Defense budget, especially the outcome of the BCA sequester, it's conceivable that we can have additional impairments. And we'll monitor the situation as the events unfold over the next year or 2.
Moving on to the guidance update for 2012. It's unchanged although on a consolidated places for the initial guidance that we provided at our Investor Conference in December 6. Consolidated 2012 sales guidance is $14.4 billion to $14.6 billion, which is a decline of 4% to 5% versus 2011. At the midpoint, we expect the sales to decline of about $670 million with about $0.5 billion of that relating to the U.S. Military drawdowns in Iraq and Afghanistan.
At the 2012 segment guidance midpoints, we expect a 19% decline in Government Services. Sales for the other 3 segments net to about flat, with growth of 2% for C3ISR, flat sales at aircraft monetization maintenance and 2% decline for Electronic Systems.
The guidance does not include the electrooptical business acquisition that we announced on December 13. We expect to complete the acquisition sometime next month as Mike indicated, and that's when we'll include it in our guidance.
For the year ending December 31, 2012, we expect the KEO business to generate sales of about $165 million, with EBITDA of about $27 million. And that's before expected synergies, transaction expenses and purchase accounting adjustments. We believe that's an excellent acquisition and we look forward to adding it to L-3.
The consolidated operating margin guidance for next year is 2.1% declining 70 basis points versus 2011. Higher pension expenses this quarter is 30 basis point reduction. The rest of the margin decline is a combination of lower sales. product sales, mix changes, pricing pressure and OSB initiatives with the largest impacts affecting the Government Services segment.
We'll continue to aggressively manage core structures and our businesses and try to deliver better margin for 2012.
Free cash flow is expected to be about $1,170,000,000, declining versus 2011 due to lower operating income and higher income tax payments. And finally, taking a look at the first quarter, we expect sales to be somewhere between $3.4 billion and $3.5 million, with EPS of $1.85 to $1.90 per share and free cash flow of about $100 million. The operating margin in the first quarter should be in the mid-9% range.
The book-to-bill for the first quarter should be close to 0.95, and we expect the full year book-to-bill to be slightly less than 1.0. That concludes my comments. And we'll go to the Q&A now.

componenttextpreview: Well, George, the couple of setting things. One is we're not down to the decimal points here on how they're going to offset. But it's not only the expansion with U-2, it's also the broader maritime Surveillance as well but will be a pickup versus the redu
componenttext: Well, George, the couple of setting things. One is we're not down to the decimal points here on how they're going to offset. But it's not only the expansion with U-2, it's also the broader maritime Surveillance as well but will be a pickup versus the reduction of Global hawk. So I think net-net, it's going to be go wash to a net, maybe a net positive because you have a new platform coming on. So we're never happy to see platforms go away or get the bucket but it's not a material then for either the segment or for L-3.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: C-5 haven't been a loss -- it's a bit very minor if you had in AM&M. We do see C-130 work, although a good chunk of it is international. The global feet of 130s has been very, very large with a lot of old rates out there. So I'm not expecting to see anyth
componenttext: C-5 haven't been a loss -- it's a bit very minor if you had in AM&M. We do see C-130 work, although a good chunk of it is international. The global feet of 130s has been very, very large with a lot of old rates out there. So I'm not expecting to see anything to speak of in terms of a reduction of what we're doing on 130s, which would typically be the work that's done in breakout. That facility is full now and it's pretty much booked up for the next year or 2, so I think we'll be okay.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just one general one. The fiscal '12 budget past, you're seeing any evidence, services awards are being delayed? What the contracting officers are doing in light of concerns about sequestration?
componenttext: And then maybe just one general one. The fiscal '12 budget past, you're seeing any evidence, services awards are being delayed? What the contracting officers are doing in light of concerns about sequestration?

componenttextpreview: No, actually I think it's a little early in the year to see that. But if I had to guess the that we might see will be an acceleration of putting money on contract, as we wind our way through the summer in get down on September 30. The part that concerns m
componenttext: No, actually I think it's a little early in the year to see that. But if I had to guess the that we might see will be an acceleration of putting money on contract, as we wind our way through the summer in get down on September 30. The part that concerns me, if that concerns me is the ability of the customers to get the money obligated by the run out of the fiscal year, because it's unexpected funds that can be swapped. So I think the real challenge our customers is to be getting the money put on contract this year, so I would expect that to be a big focus on this as we get through the third quarter.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: You mentioned there was a slip in Electronics in the fourth quarter. What were the items that slipped? And is there any chance that you didn't change your guidance for 2012, pretty big slip given you gave the guidance in December. So are any of those item
componenttext: You mentioned there was a slip in Electronics in the fourth quarter. What were the items that slipped? And is there any chance that you didn't change your guidance for 2012, pretty big slip given you gave the guidance in December. So are any of those items that you know, because they slipped actually make 2012 look a little bit easier to do?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: The answer is possibly, Cai. The sales that slipped out of the fourth quarter and Electronic Systems segment, there really wasn't any single item causing most of that slips. It was spread across several business areas in, for example training and simulati
componenttext: The answer is possibly, Cai. The sales that slipped out of the fourth quarter and Electronic Systems segment, there really wasn't any single item causing most of that slips. It was spread across several business areas in, for example training and simulation, we saw some glades on some upgrades that we're anticipating on the F-16 Mission training Center, some man packs for our Video Scout product delivery slipped out into the first quarter. We saw some reduced funding WIN-T, and to move product and how fast it to our business areas, we saw some slips on some total rate war for the U.S. Navy going into 2012. So -- but as I said I think said, because this is what happens and what we've been experiencing in the end of our short cycle businesses with the defense budget slowing and now declining. So I don't think it's unusual to see these types of slips occurring and something that we've been seeing for the better part of the year, Cai.

componenttextpreview: Okay, terrific. And then the last one in terms of cash deployment priorities, I think we have a normal dividend meeting coming up. Mike, I think you said you look for a significant increase, something -- some verbiage like that in the dividend. Maybe talk
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then the last one in terms of cash deployment priorities, I think we have a normal dividend meeting coming up. Mike, I think you said you look for a significant increase, something -- some verbiage like that in the dividend. Maybe talk to us a little bit about kind of how you're looking at this dividend. And whether it's priority in your overall cash deployment thinking has changed.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We do have our regular board meeting coming up at the beginning of February. And as has been our practice, we address the annual dividend. I take exceptions to significant in terms of increase. We look at the dividend with regards our positioning wi
componenttext: Sure. We do have our regular board meeting coming up at the beginning of February. And as has been our practice, we address the annual dividend. I take exceptions to significant in terms of increase. We look at the dividend with regards our positioning with the rest of company in terms of its yield but we are kind of in fairly in line other than this 1 outlier that its way out there, maybe yielding close to 5%. I said there's a possibility that the increase could be larger than it's been in the past. but I think over the last several years, we've increased annual run rate by about $0.20 a share. But that's a discussion that we'll have with our board. The general sentiment though is that our deployment is balanced between repurchases which leaves us the flexibility to be opportunistic in acquisitions when they come up. And of course, continue the dividend and purchase plan. We're very aggressive this year because of the weakness in the stock price and the great cash flow that we've been enjoying. And expect more of the same. The Engility spinoff is going to obviously have an impact on our recurring cash flow. There'll be a drop because the cash is going to go with Engility. And there'll be a dividend that we expect to receive that we anticipate to use to bring some of the leverage down and maintain the investment grade rating. So again all of those items will factor into the deliberations of the in the next couple of weeks.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. I guess just to go into the M&A path, Mike, Kollmorgen looks like a good transaction and there's a period of time where assets were getting the spun off periods versus the standalone transactions being taken out. And you'd commented, I
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. I guess just to go into the M&A path, Mike, Kollmorgen looks like a good transaction and there's a period of time where assets were getting the spun off periods versus the standalone transactions being taken out. And you'd commented, I think back at the Analyst Day about some of the failed auctions that have gone on in the market in the prior 12 months. What is the current activity in the market in terms of bid ask spreads and deals coming to close and realistic assessments of buyers and sellers?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that the pricing has moderated the expectation. First of all, Kollmorgen is a good example of that. It's a better price that's certainly lower than it would have been a year ago and reflects market conditions. I think that the pullbacks as we've s
componenttext: I think that the pricing has moderated the expectation. First of all, Kollmorgen is a good example of that. It's a better price that's certainly lower than it would have been a year ago and reflects market conditions. I think that the pullbacks as we've said of the prior year, meaning 2010, didn't recur to the same extent as in 2011, which indicate to me anyway that there's more realism in the expectations of sellers. Typically, January is a slow month going into the year, but there's an acceleration of deals that happened as companies complete the year-end exercises. And we see a steady supply of descriptive memorandum. I guess we call them memorandum of companies. I can tell you last year, there was no shortage. I know that we went through about 100 deals. We probably went to indications of interest on about half of them. But as you know, we closed maybe 2 with Kollmorgen being obviously the larger one and something that was very small. So being selective is kind of key here and it's not only getting companies at the right price. But there's a lot less room given where the budget is and the growth prospects right now. So you need to be very cognizant of your environment and what the prospect are, which we think we do well. And again, we're going to continue to be diligent in what we see and we're certainly interested in adding to our market-leading businesses. Where in the Kollmorgen case, we have a technology that is complementary to what we do in our EO/IR business, but it brings a different product set, a different platform set and different customer set to us and we can really lever the technology in creating more and better products. And that's what we're going to do. There's going to be more to come.

componenttext: Sales growth in the last year or 2 has been kind of flattish, because they've been -- it's completed some work or ramp vehicles. So they seem to be very well positioned in the current budget environment and budget priorities.

componenttext: OkSo through the -- on the JCA charge, that's something we have talked about on the third quarter call, and that we were expecting that there potentially could be no additional aircraft ordered. And so that's what seems to be occurring based upon all the current statements coming out of the DoD, including those from Secretary Pineda last week. So that's a more that we expect to occur obviously. The severance charges, I wouldn't characterize them as unusual because we're continually analyzing and life-sizing our business structures as we see fit given what's happening to their volumes. And I expect that we will be doing more of the same in 2012. And it wouldn't be an item that would cause a hiccup with respect to our guidance. So it's something that we do as a matter of normal course in L-3.

componenttext: Ralph, I just wanted to get back to the sales outlook that Cai was asking about earlier. You note that the Electronics segment kind of little light and those really kind of really tough across the board. We've got a lot of information last week. I'm sure some of which was not new to you but some of which was probably was new. And just when you think about the 14 4 to 14 6, can I ask for maybe some color? I mean, your growth rate is better now on the Electronic Systems because the sales came in light in 2011. And so, are we looking at a lower into the range? Or do you feel okay about it? Any other color maybe you could offer.

componenttext: Well, at this point in time, I would say we're in the middle of the range for the Electronic Systems. If we go back to how we determined and set the guidance for 2012, we deliberately made some adjustments for what we've experienced in the past couple of years. And that's as if as you know, we've risked our sales guidance feature last couple of years. And we took that into account when we determined the initial guidance for 2012. So my view is that we've adequately factored it based upon the information we have available to us. So that's why we're still comfortable with that range despite the shortfall that we have in the Electronic Systems in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the margins, the inverses that happened and you'd be able to find opportunities. And you're guiding for down 70 bps and 30 of it is pretty mechanical with the pension. And you talk about pricing pressure and volume declining, which are of course pressures. But are there opportunities there if sales come in light again to beat margins again or could you characterize that a little?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: The short answer to your question is yes. If you look at our performance in the last couple of years, we've exceeded our initial operating margin guidance in both of the years. And I said earlier, we're going to continue to manage the cost structures aggr
componenttext: The short answer to your question is yes. If you look at our performance in the last couple of years, we've exceeded our initial operating margin guidance in both of the years. And I said earlier, we're going to continue to manage the cost structures aggressively and take if you want to call them countermeasures to what's going on in the competitive and pricing environment. And that should enables us to do a little better than we're expecting in operating margin, especially if we see some softness in sales. So like I said, we're going to try to do better in our guidance in 2012. I guess I don't want to commit to it yet.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And then just finally on KEO, you hit a couple of the operating metrics. I actually missed the fall, not all of the numbers. But if you could repeat those. componenttext: I said and we expect the Kollmorgen business to generate sales of about $165 million for the full year 2012, EBITDA of about $27 million and that was before synergies. We think we're going to realize synergies there in the next year or 2. I put it in the $3 million to $5 million category, but it's going to time for us to realize it. There really isn't a lot of overlapping in terms of the products that they serve. So it's really an adjacency or expanding our EO/IR center business and enable market right now. So most of the synergies that we're going to have are going to come on the cost side with respect to the business and it augments a bigger market to us. Well, we should be able to sell some of our existing products to our new naval type customers.

componenttextpreview: Mike, you and I have talked in the past about international and trying to gauge what the real pipelines are, what's real, what isn't. You've mentioned that sometimes, it's a lot of RFP activity with no delivery on actual contract. So could you contrast th
componenttext: Mike, you and I have talked in the past about international and trying to gauge what the real pipelines are, what's real, what isn't. You've mentioned that sometimes, it's a lot of RFP activity with no delivery on actual contract. So could you contrast the areas of international that are likely to happen with those that aren't?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. One area where we continue to see more realism than is in the sensor and airborne ISR area, both customers in the Middle East and in Asia are -- have expressed a strong interest in Spider product, while other variants of some of the products of the
componenttext: Sure. One area where we continue to see more realism than is in the sensor and airborne ISR area, both customers in the Middle East and in Asia are -- have expressed a strong interest in Spider product, while other variants of some of the products of the L-3 mix including some of the advanced systems. With respect to customers in Korea, the sonar products -- and in Europe for that matter, the stoner products seem to have a strong foothold with the sales become more real and predictable. In fact, we've booked several things, the airport security equipment activity, while competitive, it's all real. I mean those they go forward with some of the longer-term areas where we are working, I believe are real but I think it's a longer sales cycle. And the ones that I just mentioned will be tank upgrades in Saudi Arabia and in Bahrain, and potentially Oman, as well as some of the AM&M work regarding had that state airplanes that are typically coming out of the United Middle East, where we expect to induct the first 747-800 and we go to make a conversion being the first on that platform widen that market. It's going to be a popular play to be upgrading given its size. So that's kind of a flavor of it. We try to avoid being the stocking ones in some of these competition where we feel just not real. When we spend resources, I'd like to spend them on things where I see we have a strategic advantage with the course and don't have the type of product or with regards to for example, the airborne ISR where we have a product that is disruptive in terms of price versus capability, price versus performance and no one has that. So we're mindful of not getting too bugged down in areas were we're not going to get any traction.

componenttext: Yes, for the year. Now, it's reflecting a market wherein we had a surge in third quarter with a book-to-bill of 1.17. So I think we're pretty upfront in saying we expected this to not recur and to be significantly lower in the fourth quarter. I don't really think that, that concern about the book-to-bill in any one particular quarter. Obviously, I'd like to look at the trailing 12-month mons trend on it. Being that close to 1 is not upsetting me that I'd like to not see it getting lower. And obviously, I'd like to see it north of 1.05 going forward. But right now, we are seeing slippage just because of the budget environment and particularly driven by services.

componenttext: Okay. And then do you expect with the fiscal '13 cuts there would be any blowback for example into the fiscal '12 funding, so where things are getting moved around they maybe can't and that's not put money after bad, let's cut these things early?

componenttext: No, I think those areas are already identified. But you raised an interesting point where, as it becomes known sooner than later, that sequestration where we're recurring more cuts on platforms would happen in '13. So your question is would they change '12 because they know it's going to end? And the answer's yes, but I can't think of anything in that league that would affect us.

componenttext: Just a few quick ones. Ralph, you said that the margin in Q1, you were looking for sort of mid-9s versus the kind of the low-10s for the full year. Can you give us some color on what kind of segment level drivers are behind that?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, generally the margins tend to be a little softer in the first quarter. And if you take a look where I think the first quarter margins will be, on a segment basis, compared to full year margin guidance, we are a little below the mark full year guidan
componenttext: Well, generally the margins tend to be a little softer in the first quarter. And if you take a look where I think the first quarter margins will be, on a segment basis, compared to full year margin guidance, we are a little below the mark full year guidance in Electronic Systems. And that's typically -- the reason is we have a very large seasonality higher fourth quarter in that segment each year, so that's what the trend is in that segment. And then, the rest of the segments tend to be towards the low end of the margin guidance range for the full year, so I consider that to be relatively normal.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then on the -- you called out the cash taxes being a headwind for '12. Can you quantify roughly what that amount is and speak if we have incremental had been in the following year in '13?
componenttext: And then on the -- you called out the cash taxes being a headwind for '12. Can you quantify roughly what that amount is and speak if we have incremental had been in the following year in '13?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: The tax headwind is going to be about $130 million versus 2011. And the reason for the increase in taxes is one, we had some unusual tax gains that reduced the effect of rate going in 2011. Those are not going to reoccur for next year. At this point in ti
componenttext: The tax headwind is going to be about $130 million versus 2011. And the reason for the increase in taxes is one, we had some unusual tax gains that reduced the effect of rate going in 2011. Those are not going to reoccur for next year. At this point in time, we don't have a R&E credit. And our expected tax rate for 2012, and that's worth roughly about $15 million or so in extra cash taxes. And then, we had some bonus depreciation that we enjoyed in 2010 and 2011, that's not repeating in 2012 unless new stimulation efforts are undertaking the tax law. That's disclosing that trend. Additionally, we're expecting a small recapture on some debt repayment that we will do this year, assuming that we repay some of the contingent convertible debt and that's in the approximately $20 million to $30 million. So...

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

componenttext: Great. And lastly, just a follow up on Howard's question, a point of clarification. You said get the Engility plus NSS guidance for '12 envisioned a decline in both spaces. componenttext: So, it's in line with that. Most of the downturn -- or most of the reduction already happened in our fourth quarter. In the fourth quarter of 2011, the Government Services segment, sales were down 19%. So that's kind of resetting to a level that we expect to be at for most of 2012.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the previous question on the degree of conservatism in the 2012 top line guidance. Because just from a high level, it looks like your sort of forecasting a similar total rate of revenue decline, and you're exiting '11 with a lower a
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the previous question on the degree of conservatism in the 2012 top line guidance. Because just from a high level, it looks like your sort of forecasting a similar total rate of revenue decline, and you're exiting '11 with a lower average of the last 12-month book-to-bill, and you have $700 million of recompete that's in, I guess, your more competitive segment in the current environment. And the budget environment isn't really different. So can you maybe just elaborate on what specifically -- what programs you've haircut or what win potentials are out there that you're not really factoring? Maybe just give a little more granular on why it's more conservative in '12 than it was in '11?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me first state that I think our sales guidance is appropriate for 2012. I don't want to suggest that it's conservative. I said it's conservative in the context of what we've experienced in the last couple of years. So I think it's the correct
componenttext: Sure. So let me first state that I think our sales guidance is appropriate for 2012. I don't want to suggest that it's conservative. I said it's conservative in the context of what we've experienced in the last couple of years. So I think it's the correct appropriate sales guidance. You look at 2012 compare it to 2011, we had some headwinds in 2011 that we're not going to have in 2012, is a big example of that. Plus the decline in JCA revenue is greater in '11 that in is in '12. So that's going to help to offset some of the other decline trends that we're experiencing in 2012. With respect to the major competitions and the Aircraft Modernization and Maintenance segments, and that's really the only segment in 2012 and any major re-competes and I define a major recompete as one that those and had sales in excess of $100 million per year. We explained that in the Investor Conference so we think we adequately factored what will happen on those to 2 re-competitions and to our sales guidance. And it's also mitigated by the fact that when those new contacts would begin with the larger one being, it doesn't happen until October 1.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. So specifically on those, I mean have you factored that it's fairly likely you lose them just because you've got an environment where you're going to have 1 or 2 guys in there bidding very low margins in all likelihood or not?
componenttext: Right. So specifically on those, I mean have you factored that it's fairly likely you lose them just because you've got an environment where you're going to have 1 or 2 guys in there bidding very low margins in all likelihood or not?

componenttextpreview: I'll just say that we factored appropriately for what could happen in the competitive environment there.
componenttext: I'll just say that we factored appropriately for what could happen in the competitive environment there.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one more higher-level question, I guess. In this environment where revenue is declining and margins are compressing, the earnings, the bottom line earnings of the company have stayed fairly flattish. And obviously, the share repurchase prog
componenttext: Okay. And then one more higher-level question, I guess. In this environment where revenue is declining and margins are compressing, the earnings, the bottom line earnings of the company have stayed fairly flattish. And obviously, the share repurchase program is the reason for that and Paramount to that is your ability to keep generated free cash the way you have. You've surprised us positively about how strong your free cash flow has remained and where you've guided it to in '12 given a tougher environment. So, Mike, I just wondered if you could speak longer term to the sustainability of that cash flow generation for the company going forward.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, I think that the strength of our cash flow has been pretty much consistent throughout most of the company history. We have always been a strong generator of cash. What's driving the earnings of course is how we're deploying that cash, n
componenttext: Yes. First of all, I think that the strength of our cash flow has been pretty much consistent throughout most of the company history. We have always been a strong generator of cash. What's driving the earnings of course is how we're deploying that cash, not only with the repurchase program, but also with accretive acquisitions and the fact that we've refinanced a good portion of our debt and lowered our interest charges consistently over the past 2 or 3 years or so. So in my experience, in history in this industry is that as volume declines, the working capital that we have invested in a particular program will liquidate and will keep the cash flow strong. And I go back to managing through the declines that went on in the early-to-mid '90s, and that was the effect that we saw, as working capital was liquidity, more cash gets generated. Candidly, I thought that will be in a place where our cash flow was lower because we're investing it in the new facilities and technologies because the top line's growing and I think we'll all agree we'd be happier. But it does give us a natural push in this environment that whether these declines that we're confident as long as we manage our programs, they'll take on undaunted risks, which we don't plan on. That we will be able to maintain the consistent cash flow generation that we have and be able to use the deployment of that cash to mature that bottom line and keep it modestly growing. That's our goal.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: So if we have a 5-year budget downturn that translates into revenue declines in margin compression for that period of time, you guys think this sort of 135-ish percent free cash to net income conversion is sustainable through that rough order of magnitude
componenttext: So if we have a 5-year budget downturn that translates into revenue declines in margin compression for that period of time, you guys think this sort of 135-ish percent free cash to net income conversion is sustainable through that rough order of magnitude?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the conversion rate from net income to free cash flow is sustainable because of the reasons why it happens and those are going to remain intact even as we go from the cyclical downturn. And in addition to that, what happens to our operating income i
componenttext: Well, the conversion rate from net income to free cash flow is sustainable because of the reasons why it happens and those are going to remain intact even as we go from the cyclical downturn. And in addition to that, what happens to our operating income is going to be good indicator of what happens to free cash flow in total. But we're going to continue to have very strong conversion when we convert substantially more of our net income to cash flow. And I just said, it's been 135% or so and that type of ratio is going to -- should be sustainable.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Ruttenbur of Morgan Keegan.

componenttextpreview: Can we talk about acquisitions possibly outside of the defense sector? What your plans are? Areas that you'd like to acquire to maybe diversify if that is in fact your plans? And multiples you'd be looking at paying the poser something higher to diversify
componenttext: Can we talk about acquisitions possibly outside of the defense sector? What your plans are? Areas that you'd like to acquire to maybe diversify if that is in fact your plans? And multiples you'd be looking at paying the poser something higher to diversify?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: The answer, Brian is no because we have no plans to get outside of our dealings. We have learned in the '90s is where defense companies gotten off the reservation and things like space Communications and whatnot, it was not a happy story. So I would rathe
componenttext: The answer, Brian is no because we have no plans to get outside of our dealings. We have learned in the '90s is where defense companies gotten off the reservation and things like space Communications and whatnot, it was not a happy story. So I would rather focus you on what things we can do in L-3 to move our portfolio that's more in those segments of defense that are growing or in areas of adjacency. I referenced the green taxi or green taxi earlier in this conversation where things that IT and healthcare for example, which by way don't read that I'm planning anything in that space. I'm just using it as an example. We can take the technology that we are comfortable with and bring it to a broader marketplace and that could be customers in the DoD and the intercommunity and the development or the commercial space in certain areas of commercial space, certainly more the industrial product areas because we're not built to those kind of distribution channels. And those are the areas that we focus on and our group presidents to come in with ideas for expanding their market applications. And some of could be using EO/IR or center technology for things like agriculture or domestic security means of guarding critical infrastructure pipelines point et cetera. So I mean we are committed to staying very close to home in terms of our areas and not wandering too far outside our areas of expertise. But we have a treasure of technology here. And I think with a little bit of innovation and imagination. They are applicable outside the quarter marketplace.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can I interpret that, that you don't plan to make acquisitions in the commercial space? You're going to try to use your existing technology getting into there? Or would you -- if you have an existing technology and you find a copy out there, you would als
componenttext: Can I interpret that, that you don't plan to make acquisitions in the commercial space? You're going to try to use your existing technology getting into there? Or would you -- if you have an existing technology and you find a copy out there, you would also be opportunistic in that commercial space?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, you can interpret it that way. That's fair. No, I'm not going to complete the underrated commercial space. There are no plans to that and we are opportunistic. If we see something in commercial company where we could take existing technology buy it a
componenttext: Yes, you can interpret it that way. That's fair. No, I'm not going to complete the underrated commercial space. There are no plans to that and we are opportunistic. If we see something in commercial company where we could take existing technology buy it at a reasonable price and it started as technology absorption into some of our system that make our products better and more desirable for our customers, we will do that and we've done that in the past.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can just talk on the services side, about how your win rate on the re-competes has track this quarter? And also, Mike, if the margin issues you talked about in December have continued. You said that some of the margins on these we c
componenttext: I was wondering if you can just talk on the services side, about how your win rate on the re-competes has track this quarter? And also, Mike, if the margin issues you talked about in December have continued. You said that some of the margins on these we compete of getting harder.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me talk to the margins and Ralph can talk about the win rate statistics. But yes I mean the margins are very directly with the level of commodity type services you're getting. It's directly a function of we see a competition where you have 12 to 15 co
componenttext: Let me talk to the margins and Ralph can talk about the win rate statistics. But yes I mean the margins are very directly with the level of commodity type services you're getting. It's directly a function of we see a competition where you have 12 to 15 companies show up, you have 1 where there's 3, depending on what the work to be done is. So there is clearly more margin compression in areas we have more competitors. If you wanted my perspective on that phenomenon as a cycle, what we've seen over the past cycles is that when that happens, you get companies that invariably will win on price that are not qualified to do the work or just really don't have the experience. And so, I caught a pendulum on the fact that we're all the way on the technical capability the right now. That I would expect to transition back to something more normal over years. And unfortunately, once a customer has a couple of bad experiences with contracts that aren't capable of doing the work, they're just qualifying them on price only. We've already experienced a pretty good drop in the composite margins in services to date. So of course, the question is how much more is there to go. Well I think after the Engility spinoff, the more stable Engility has experienced the drop more or has been meeting in terms of the volume of drop more than the rest of our services business. In terms of L-3's guidance just for example, our 2012 guidance is about 10.1% of the midpoint on margins post Engility, but you've taken up 40 basis points. You can see where the bulk of that weakness has been happening. In terms of win rate, Ralph, what can you have on the win rates?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: The win rates in the fourth quarter on re-competitions was probably near 75%. That said, we didn't have a lot of re-competitions and decisions that occurred in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: The win rates in the fourth quarter on re-competitions was probably near 75%. That said, we didn't have a lot of re-competitions and decisions that occurred in the fourth quarter.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

componenttext: Just finally, on Engility, you mentioned that there was going to be a dividend which is used to reduce leverage. Have you sized how big that dividend could be?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: We gave our range. I think we said in the $400 million to $500 million neighborhood. But that's a number we're not signing up to at this point because it's going to be based on market conditions at the time. The targeted credit rating for the business, wh
componenttext: We gave our range. I think we said in the $400 million to $500 million neighborhood. But that's a number we're not signing up to at this point because it's going to be based on market conditions at the time. The targeted credit rating for the business, what our board wants to approved based on the input from some of the expert in the area, notably the bankers and the overall credit environment. But based on what we've seen in similar transactions -- and by the way, the discussions with the DoD with the team we expect an inquiry as to the amount of leverage going to put on the company and that's not move. So there's a number of holders to take over but we think that, that's a reasonable expectation. If it came in at a little lower or a little higher, we'll manage it.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ralph, you had commented on shorter cycles in the business. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about that would that is having any significant impact in your near-term visibility on that business.
componenttext: Ralph, you had commented on shorter cycles in the business. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about that would that is having any significant impact in your near-term visibility on that business.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: I talked about the short versus long cycle nature of L-3 business at the investor conference. You may recall I said that we expect about half of our sales for 2012 to come out of funded backlog. Another 41% to come out of follow-on business and the rest w
componenttext: I talked about the short versus long cycle nature of L-3 business at the investor conference. You may recall I said that we expect about half of our sales for 2012 to come out of funded backlog. Another 41% to come out of follow-on business and the rest will be re-competes and new business. So if you look at Electronic Systems, there's probably about 55% coming out of funded backlog. So a little more than the company average, but it tells you that this is a large amount of follow-on work to be booked to make the full year sales, and that's typically what's been. And that introduces the risk around short cycle. So in the past, when the budget was growing year-after-year, the short cycle nature of the business tended to help us because funds just seem to be more -- just seem to pop up when you wouldn't expect them and it costs upside on a follow on basis. Now in the declining budget situation, you have the inverse happening where there's more risk with respect to the follow-on work and that can be just due to some of the things that you talked about earlier today, some hesitation on the part of procurement officials concerning future budget levels. There's been some reprogramming that's happened in the past few years as the budgets have gotten tighter and is likely to continue and that's what creates the short cycle risk on the follow-on orders that we're seeing Electronic Systems and frankly, in other segments as well. So sooner or later, the cycle catches up to other businesses short or long, I'll just leave you with that thought.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, well I'm happy that we had a robust Q&A period although we're running a little bit over. We feel confident given where the DoD came out over the last couple of weeks on their priorities and choices that L-3 is positioned well, though not immune from
componenttext: Okay, well I'm happy that we had a robust Q&A period although we're running a little bit over. We feel confident given where the DoD came out over the last couple of weeks on their priorities and choices that L-3 is positioned well, though not immune from the declines in the budget. There's no major structural issues I see within the company where we're just in the business that we are not going to be positioned and continue to be leaving players in the new world order of defense spending. And finally, I think watch this year is going to be the disconnect between the budget that's been passed and the fact that sequestration has been triggered and how Congress and the DoD get that reconciled and corrected. We'll keep our eye under the course because that's going to affect planning for 2013 and beyond. Given the statements that have been made though by both the Office of the President as well as the Pentagon and the members of Congress, there seems to be some unison -- and the military leadership by the way that the structure for the U.S. Armed Forces needs to be not hallowed out and have the technology edge that it enjoys today. And those comments give you comfort that we're positioned in good areas within L-3. So we'll speak with you again at the end of the first quarter in April and thanks for joining us. Bye-bye.
